questions.text: In which clinical test is the "Ring test" precipitation reaction applied, and what is its primary use?

choices.text: Ascoli’s thermo precipitin test for detecting anthrax antigens
VDRL test for detecting syphilis
Lancefield technique for grouping mycobacteria
Kahn test for detecting lupus antibodies

questions.solution:
The Ring test is utilized in Ascoli's thermo precipitin test to detect the presence of anthrax antigens. This reaction is based on a precipitation reaction in a liquid medium. In this test, the suspected antigen is layered over an antiserum in a narrow tube, and a precipitate forms at the interface if anthrax antigens are present.

 

Precipitation Reactions

Soluble antigen and antibody combine to form antigen-antibody complex in the presence of electrolytes (e.g., NaCl) at the right temperature and pH to form an insoluble precipitate.

 

Mechanism of precipitation

Lattice hypothesis by Marrack:

  • Precipitation results when a large lattice forms from alternating antigen and antibody molecules in the zone of equivalence
  • In the Zones of antigen or antibody excess, the lattice does not enlarge, as the valencies of the antibody and the antigen, respectively, are fully satisfied.
    • Prozone phenomenon occurs when there is too much antigen in relation to the amount of antibody in the test.
    • Postzone phenomenon occurs when there is too much antigen in relation to the amount of antibody in the test.

Types:

  • Precipitation reaction in liquid
  • Precipitation reaction in the gel

 

Precipitation reaction in liquid

  • Ring test
  • Flocculation tests

Ring test:

  • Antigen layered over antiserum in a narrow tube; precipitate forms at the interface
  • Application:
    • Ascoli's thermo precipitin test - diagnosis of anthrax (Option A)
    • Grouping of streptococci by the Lancefield technique (Option C ruled out)

Flocculation tests

  • Slide test:
    • Antigen and the antiserum (antibody) are placed on a slide and mixed by shaking; floccules appear
    • Application: VDRL test for syphilis (Option B ruled out)
  • Tube test:
    • Tube is used instead of a slide
    • Application: Kahn test for syphilis (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with recurrent infections and a history of autoimmune disease. Laboratory tests reveal a deficiency in complement component C3. Which of the following is the most likely consequence of this deficiency?

choices.text: Increased susceptibility to infections by Neisseria meningitidis
Impaired opsonization and phagocytosis, leading to severe bacterial infections
Development of hereditary angioneurotic oedema
Enhanced immune complex clearance and reduced inflammation

questions.solution:
Impaired opsonization and phagocytosis due to C3 deficiency increases susceptibility to severe bacterial infections, particularly from pyogenic bacteria.

 

Complement Deficiency:

  • Definition: Complement deficiencies arise from genetic defects in complement components or regulatory proteins, compromising both innate and acquired immunity.
  • Clinical Manifestations: Vary from mild recurrent infections to severe life-threatening conditions.

Consequences of Complement Deficiency:

  • Impaired Immune Clearance: Reduced ability to clear microbial antigens and immune complexes leads to:
    • Recurrent Infections:
      • Increased susceptibility to bacterial and fungal infections, especially with C3 deficiencies.
      • Common infections include pneumonia, skin infections, and sepsis due to pyogenic bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae).
    • Neisserial Infections:
      • Terminal complement deficiencies (C5-C9) increase susceptibility to Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, leading to meningitis, septicaemia, and gonorrhoea. (Option A ruled out)
    • Autoimmune Diseases:
      • It is associated with conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) due to impaired clearance of immune complexes, resulting in tissue deposition, inflammation, and damage.

Specific Deficiencies and Associated Syndromes:

 

Deficiency

Condition/Clinical Manifestation

C1 Inhibitor Deficiency (Option C ruled out)

Hereditary angioneurotic oedema: Uncontrolled activation of classical pathway causes episodic swelling (can be life-threatening).

C3 Deficiency

Increased susceptibility to severe recurrent pyogenic infections; impaired opsonization, phagocytosis, and immune complex clearance.

C5-C9 Deficiencies

Increased susceptibility to bacteraemia, especially with Gram-negative diplococci; impaired formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC).

 

Enhanced immune complex clearance and reduced inflammation (option D) are incorrect, as C3 deficiency leads to impaired clearance and increased inflammation due to the accumulation of immune complexes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the pathways of complement activation?

choices.text: The classical pathway is triggered by the spontaneous hydrolysis of C3 and does not require antibodies.
The alternative pathway is initiated by the binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to mannose residues on pathogens.
The lectin pathway involves the binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes, leading to the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC).
All three pathways converge at the formation of C3 convertase, which cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All three pathways converge at the formation of C3 convertase, which cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b.

Explanation:

The convergence of the pathways at C3 convertase is crucial for activating the complement cascade, regardless of the pathway triggered. This is a key feature of the complement system, allowing for a unified response to pathogen invasion.

 

Complement System:

  • Definition: A complex network of at least 30 proteins in the blood, crucial for innate and acquired immunity.
  • Functions:
    • Lysis: Directly kills pathogens by forming membrane pores.
    • Opsonization: Coats pathogens to enhance recognition and uptake by phagocytes.
    • Immune Clearance: Removes immune complexes from circulation.
    • Inflammation: Triggers release of mediators, recruiting immune cells.

Pathways of Complement Activation:

 

Pathway

Trigger Mechanism

Key Components Involved

Classical Pathway

Binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes (Option A ruled out)

C1q, C3 convertase, Membrane Attack Complex (MAC)

Alternative Pathway

Direct binding of complement proteins to pathogens (Option B ruled out)

C3, factors B and D, C3 convertase

Lectin Pathway

Binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to mannose (Option C ruled out)

MBL, MASP1, MASP2, C4, C2, C3 convertase

 

Key Points:

  • Convergence: All pathways converge at the formation of the C3 convertase.
  • C3 Convertase: Cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b, leading to the formation of C5 convertase and, ultimately, MAC.
  • Regulation: The complement system is tightly regulated to prevent excessive activation and damage to host tissues.
  • Regulatory Proteins: Include inhibitors and inactivators that control the cascade.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics of Immunochromatographic Card Tests is NOT accurate?

choices.text: A) They provide rapid results, often within 15-30 minutes.
B) The tests for Hepatitis B can detect both antibodies and antigens.
C) They are primarily used in well-equipped laboratory settings only.
D) The sensitivity and specificity of these tests can be greater than 90%.

questions.solution:
These tests are designed for use in resource-limited settings and can be used in various environments.

 

Immunochromatographic Card Tests:

  • Purpose: Rapid detection of infectious diseases including Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, COVID-19, and malaria.
  • Advantages:
    • Quick results (15-30 minutes) (Option A ruled out)
    • High sensitivity and specificity
    • Useful in resource-limited settings

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the indirect immunofluorescence test?

choices.text: A) It requires specific fluorescent conjugates for each antigen being tested.
It uses an antiglobulin fluorescent conjugate to detect any human antibody, allowing for broader application.
It directly labels antigens with a fluorescent dye for visualisation.
It is primarily used to detect antigens in brain smears, such as in rabies diagnosis.

questions.solution:
The indirect immunofluorescence test uses a single anti-human globulin fluorescent conjugate, making it versatile and reducing the need for multiple conjugates.

 

Immunofluorescence:

  • Technique to visualise antigen-antibody interactions using fluorescent dyes.
  • Developed by Coons et al. in 1942.
  • Diagnostic and research applications for identifying antigens in tissues.

 

Principle of Immunofluorescence:

  • Fluorescence: A substance absorbs specific light wavelengths and emits light at a longer wavelength.
  • Fluorescent Dyes: Appear bright when exposed to UV light, allowing visualisation of antibody-bound antigens under a microscope.


 

Types of Immunofluorescence Tests:

 

Type

Description

Example

Limitation

Direct Immunofluorescence

Detects antigen directly using a fluorescent-labelled antibody.

(Option C ruled out)

Rabies diagnosis via brain smears

(Option D ruled out)

Requires separate fluorescent conjugates for each antigen.

(Option A ruled out)

Indirect Immunofluorescence

It uses antiglobulin fluorescent conjugate to detect human antibodies, enhancing versatility.

Fluorescent treponemal antibody test for syphilis

Allows the use of a single anti-human conjugate.


 

Procedure for Indirect Immunofluorescence (e.g., Treponemal Antibody Test):

  1. Apply a drop of patient serum on a T. N pallidum smear.
  2. Incubate and wash to remove unbound components, leaving a bound antibody.
  3. Add fluorescent-labelled anti-human gamma globulin; binds to the patient’s antibody on treponemes.
  4. Wash off unbound conjugates; examine under UV light.
  5. Positive test: Treponemes fluoresce against a dark background.


 

Applications of Fluorescent Dyes in Immunology:

  • Conjugation with Complement Proteins: Enables detection of antigens/antibodies.
  • Sandwich Technique: Used to detect antibodies involving a labelled secondary antibody.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Combines serology specificity with histology for tissue visualisation.
  • Flow Cytometry: Fluorescence-based cell identification and counting with specific markers.

 

Advantages and Disadvantages of Immunofluorescence:

 

Advantages

Disadvantages

High sensitivity for detecting small amounts of antigen/antibody.

Non-specific fluorescence due to autofluorescence or non-specific binding.

High specificity with target-specific antibodies.

Photobleaching (loss of fluorescence over time with light exposure).

Versatile: applicable to various samples (tissues, cells, microorganisms).

High cost of equipment and reagents.

Allows direct visualisation, aiding interpretation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Chemiluminescent Immunoassays (CLIA) is TRUE?

choices.text: A) CLIA exclusively uses fluorescent dyes to detect antibodies in clinical samples.
The sensitivity of the VITROS® SARS-CoV-2 Ag Test is reported to be 94.3%.
CLIA methods have lower diagnostic accuracy compared to traditional serological tests.
Neutralising antibody levels against SARS-CoV-2 can only be detected using RT-PCR

questions.solution:
The sensitivity of the VITROS® SARS-CoV-2 Ag Test is reported to be 94.3% is true, as it accurately reflects the performance metrics of this CLIA-based antigen detection kit.

 

Chemiluminescent Immunoassays (CLIA):

  • Definition: Advanced diagnostic tools using chemiluminescence to detect specific antibodies or antigens in clinical samples.
  • Mechanism:
    • Utilises a chemiluminescent reaction that emits light due to a chemical reaction. (Option A ruled out)
    • Highly sensitive; capable of detecting low analyte concentrations in serum or plasma. (Option C ruled out)

 

Applications in SARS-CoV-2 Detection:

 

Application

Details

Performance Metrics

Neutralising Antibodies

Automated CLIA was developed for detecting neutralising antibody (NAb) levels against SARS-CoV-2.

Sensitivity: 87.4%

Specificity: 78.1%

Antigen Detection

VITROS® SARS-CoV-2 Ag Test evaluated against RT-PCR and rapid antigen tests (RATs).

Sensitivity: 94.3%

Specificity: 100%

 

Comparative Performance:

  • Serological Assays: CLIA methods effectively detected SARS-CoV-2 antibodies over time.
    • Some assays maintained high sensitivity, while others showed reduced performance after several months.
    • Indicates the necessity for periodic reassessment of assay parameters.

Diagnostic Accuracy:

  • Clinical Settings: Different CLIA methodologies showed diagnostic accuracies.
    • Sensitivities exceeding 85% for previous COVID-19 infections.
    • High specificity across various tests, confirming CLIA's reliability in serological testing.

 

Neutralising antibody levels against SARS-CoV-2 can only be detected using RT-PCR (Option D), which is incorrect because specific automated CLIA assays are developed to detect neutralising antibodies, not just RT-PCR.

questions.text: Which type of ELISA involves an antigen in the sample competing with a known antigen for a limited amount of antibody, resulting in an inverse colour change curve?

choices.text: A) Sandwich ELISA
B) Indirect ELISA
C) Competitive ELISA
D) Capture ELISA

questions.solution:
Competitive ELISA involves competition between the unknown antigen (sample) and a known antigen for binding to a limited amount of antibody. Higher antigen levels result in less colour change, creating an inverse curve.

 

ELISA Types:

ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) is a popular serological method known for its versatility, sensitivity, simplicity, and cost-effectiveness. It is commonly used in diagnostic labs due to commercial test kits and automation options.

Types of ELISA:

 

Type

Description

Application Example

Homogeneous ELISA

One-step procedure; no separation of bound and free fractions needed.

Suitable for analysing haptens like drugs.

Enzyme-multiplied immunoassay technique (EMIT) for drug detection

Heterogeneous ELISA

Multi-step process requiring separation of bound and free fractions (e.g., by centrifugation).

Commonly used for microbial antigen and antibody detection.

Standard ELISA

 

ELISA Methods:

 

Method

Description

Example

Sandwich ELISA (Option A ruled out)

Used to detect antigens by capturing them between two antibodies (capture and detection antibodies).

Detection of rotavirus antigen in faeces

Indirect ELISA (Option B ruled out)

Used to detect antibodies in the sample.

Anti-HIV antibody test

Competitive ELISA

Antigen in the sample competes with known antigen for a limited amount of antibody; produces an inverse curve (less colour at higher antigen levels).

Hapten detection

Capture ELISA (Option D ruled out)

Highly specific for detecting specific antigens.

Various immunometric tests

 

Sandwich ELISA Procedure:

  1. Coating: Coat microtiter wells with goat anti-rotavirus antibody; add sample and incubate (overnight at 4°C or 2 hours at 37°C).
  2. Detection Antibody: Add enzyme-labelled anti-rotavirus antibody (e.g., with alkaline phosphatase) and incubate.
  3. Substrate Addition: Add para-nitrophenyl phosphate; enzyme activity causes colour change if rotavirus is present.
  4. Interpretation: Yellow colour development confirms a positive test; the ELISA reader provides quantitative colour readings.

 

ELISA Modifications:

 

Modification

Description and Application

Example

Cylinder/Cassette ELISA

For rapid, small-scale testing using disposable cassettes.

Results are read visually without special equipment.

Dot Blot Assay for HIV detection

Sandwich ELISA

Used specifically for antigen detection.

Detection of food toxins and adulterants

 

Key Applications of ELISA:

  • Disease Diagnosis: HIV, hepatitis, and other infectious diseases.

Food Safety: Detection of toxins and adulterants.

questions.text: In the Complement Fixation Test (CFT), what indicates a positive result?

choices.text: Lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs)
Formation of an immune complex between antigen and antibody
No lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs)
Presence of active complement in the serum

questions.solution:
No lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs) indicates a positive CFT. In a positive test, the complement is fixed by the immune complex formed between antigen and antibody, leaving no free complement to lyse the SRBCs.

 

Complement Fixation Test (CFT):

  • Purpose: Detects specific antigens or antibodies in serum by measuring complement fixation.
  • Principle: Immune complex (antigen-antibody binding) fixes complement, which is then detected using sensitised sheep red blood cells (SRBCs).

Procedure of CFT:

 

Step

Description

Step 1: Complement Fixation

1. Heat patient serum to inactivate native complement.

2. Add known antigen or antibody and complement.

3. Immune complex fixes the complement if a specific antigen or antibody is present.

Step 2: Indicator Stage

1. Add sensitised SRBCs (coated with amboceptor) to the mixture.

2. Positive CFT: Complement fixed, no SRBC lysis.

3. Negative CFT: Free complement lyses SRBCs.

 

Applications:

  • Sensitivity: Detects 0.04 mg of antibody nitrogen and 0.1 mg of antigen.
  • Example: Wassermann reaction for syphilis diagnosis.

Limitations:

  • Requires precise standardisation of reagents.
  • Sera may contain non-specific complement inhibitors, leading to false positives.

Indirect Complement Fixation Test:

  • Modification: Used for sera that cannot fix guinea pig complement (e.g., avian/mammalian sera).
  • Method: Add standard antiserum that can fix complement after the first CFT stage.
    • Positive Result: Hemolysis occurs if antigen-antibody binding has consumed the complement.

Other Complement-Dependent Serological Tests:

 

Test Type

Description

Immune Adherence

Bacteria aggregate and adhere to cells (e.g., erythrocytes) in the presence of complement and specific antibodies.

Immobilisation Test

Antibodies inhibit bacterial motility with complement (e.g., Treponema pallidum immobilisation test).

Cytolytic/Cytocidal Tests

Bacteria are lysed or killed when mixed with specific antibodies and complement.

 

Lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs) (Option A) indicates a negative result, as it shows that the complement was not fixed, and the SRBCs are free to be lysed.

 

Formation of an immune complex (Option B) occurs in both positive and negative results but does not directly indicate a positive outcome.

 

Presence of active complement in the serum (Option C) before heating could interfere with the test, but it is not an indicator of a positive result.

questions.text: A 30-year-old Rh-negative G2P1L1 woman is evaluated during her routine prenatal visit. What would be the significance of performing an indirect Coombs test at this stage?

choices.text: To determine the mother’s ABO blood type
To check for antibodies against Rh-positive blood
To confirm the sensitization of red cells with antibodies in the fetus
All of the above

questions.solution:
The indirect Coombs test checks for antibodies in the mother’s serum that may attack Rh-positive red blood cells, which is important at this stage in assessing the risk of Rh incompatibility in the fetus.

 

Coombs (Antiglobulin) Test

Originally developed for the detection of anti-Rh antibodies that do not agglutinate Rh-positive erythrocytes in saline.

Principle:

  • Incomplete anti-Rh antibodies coat Rh-positive red cells without causing agglutination.
  • When these coated cells are washed and treated with Coombs serum (anti-human globulin), agglutination occurs

Types:

  • Direct Coombs Test: Detects in vivo sensitization of red cells with antibodies, used in cases like hemolytic disease of the newborn due to Rh incompatibility (sample for test is blood from the baby) (Option C ruled out)
  • Indirect Coombs Test: Detects in vitro sensitization by adding patient serum to test red cells, useful for blood transfusion compatibility and antibody screening (sample for test is blood from the mother)

 

Applications:

  • Initially, for anti-Rh antibody detection.
  • It also detects other incomplete or non-agglutinating antibodies, such as in brucellosis.

 

To determine the mother’s ABO blood type (Option A): It is important to know the mother’s ABO blood type for managing potential blood group incompatibilities. However, it is not the primary purpose of the indirect Coombs test at this stage, especially considering she is Rh-negative and having a second pregnancy. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which type of agglutination test is typically used for blood typing?

choices.text: Heterophile Agglutination test
Co-agglutination test
Direct Agglutination test
Passive Agglutination test

questions.solution:
Direct agglutination refers to the clumping of particles (such as cells) that have specific antigens on their surface in the presence of corresponding antibodies. When blood is mixed with anti-A or anti-B antibodies, direct agglutination occurs if the specific antigens are present in the red blood cells.

 

Agglutination Reactions

  • Clumping of particulate antigens with specific antibodies in the presence of electrolytes at the right temperature and pH
  • More sensitive than precipitation for antibody detection

Principle:

  • Agglutination occurs optimally when antigens and antibodies react in equivalent proportions
  • The zone phenomenon may be seen when either an antibody or an antigen is in excess
  • Incomplete or monovalent antibodies do not cause agglutination, though they combine with the antigen

Types

Direct (Active) Agglutination: Antibody reacts directly with particulate antigen

  • Slide Agglutination: Used for bacterial identification, blood grouping, and cross-matching (Option C)
  • Tube Agglutination: Quantitative; used in diagnosing brucellosis, typhus, and for the Widal test
  • Heterophile Agglutination Tests: (Option A ruled out)
    • Weil-Felix Reaction: Diagnoses typhus fevers
    • Streptococcus MG Test: Diagnoses primary atypical pneumonia
    • Paul-Bunnell Test: For infectious mononucleosis
  • Coombs (Antiglobulin) Test: Detects anti-Rh antibodies and antibodies in brucellosis

Indirect (passive) Agglutination: Soluble antigens attached to carrier particles make agglutination tests more sensitive and convenient (Option D ruled out)

  • Carrier Particles: Red blood cells, latex particles, or bentonite
  • Hemagglutination: Detects rheumatoid arthritis (RA) factor
  • Latex Agglutination: Detects anti-streptolysin O (ASO), C-reactive protein (CRP), RA factor, and human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG)
  • Co-agglutination: Uses Staphylococcus aureus with Protein A to bind antibodies, causing visible clumping when reacting with specific antigens (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: The image below shows a precipitation test in a gel medium in which a circular precipitation pattern is formed due to an antigen-antibody reaction. What type of precipitation test in the gel does this image depict?

choices.text: Ouchterlony Procedure
Radial immunodiffusion
Oakley-Fulthorpe Procedure
Counterimmunoelectrophoresis

questions.solution:
In radial immunodiffusion (single diffusion two-dimension), the antigen is placed in a central well and diffuses outward through a gel containing evenly distributed antibodies. As the antigen diffuses radially, it forms a circular precipitation ring. The size of this ring is proportional to the antigen concentration.

 

Precipitation Reactions in Gel

  • Immunodiffusion in a soft agar or agarose gel forms visible, stable bands of precipitation that can be stained
  • Advantages: Distinct, preservable precipitation bands allow easy observation of different antigens

Types and Modifications:

  • One-Dimension: Agar gel in a test tube
  • Two-Dimension: Agar gel on a flat surface (slide or petri dish)

Single Diffusion: Antigen diffuses towards antibody

  • One-Dimension (Oudin Procedure)
  • Two-Dimension (Radial Immunodiffusion): Antigen diffuses radially, forming ring-shaped bands (Option B)
    • Application: Screening sera for antibodies (e.g., influenza viruses)

Double Diffusion: Antigen and antibody move toward each other.

  • One-Dimension (Oakley-Fulthorpe Procedure) (Option C ruled out)
  • Two-Dimension (Ouchterlony Procedure): (Option A ruled out)
    • Compares different antigens and antisera directly.
    • Application: Elek test for diphtheria toxigenicity.

Immunoelectrophoresis:

  • Involves the electrophoretic separation of a composite antigen (such as serum) into its constituent proteins, followed by immunodiffusion against its antiserum, resulting in separate precipitin lines, indicating a reaction between each individual protein with its antibody.

Electroimmunodiffusion:

Combines electrophoresis and immunodiffusion by electrically driving antigen and antibody diffusion.

  • Counterimmunoelectrophoresis (CIE): (Option D ruled out)
    • Electrophoresis of antigen and antibody in opposite directions; precipitation forms between them.
    • Application: Detects antigens like alpha-fetoprotein and specific antigens of Cryptococcus and Meningococcus in cerebrospinal fluid.

  • Rocket Electrophoresis (One-Dimension Single Diffusion):
    • Antigen, in increasing concentrations, is placed in wells punched in the set gel.
    • The antigen is then electrophoresed into the antibody-containing agarose
    • Application: Quantitative estimation of antigens

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes a pro-antigen?

choices.text: A molecule that binds to carrier proteins to become immunogenic and trigger an immune response.
A substance that directly triggers an immune response without any modification.
A molecule that requires metabolic conversion into reactive intermediates to become immunogenic.
A compound that can bind to antibodies but does not provoke a full immune response without a carrier protein.

questions.solution:
Pro-antigens need metabolic conversion to form reactive intermediates, which then bind to proteins to trigger immune responses.

 

Haptens, Pro-Antigens, and Incomplete Antigens:

 

Term

Definition

Mechanism

Clinical Relevance

Haptens

LMW compounds (<1000 Da) that require binding to carrier proteins to trigger immune response

Bind to proteins to form conjugates, recognized by T cells, stimulating humoral and cellular responses (Option A ruled out)

Associated with allergic contact dermatitis (e.g., nickel, penicillin)

Pro-Antigens

Substances needing metabolic conversion to become immunogenic (Option B ruled out)

Metabolized into reactive intermediates, then bind proteins, forming immune-triggering complexes

Example: Urushiol in poison ivy, requiring activation to cause allergy

Incomplete Antigens

Molecules that bind to antibodies or T-cell receptors but don’t provoke full immune response alone (Option D ruled out)

Require attachment to larger carrier molecules to be immunogenic

Involved in immune tolerance and sensitization mechanisms

questions.text: Which immunoglobulin is most closely associated with the early stages of B cell response and is found alongside IgM on unstimulated B lymphocytes?

choices.text: IgA
IgD
IgE
All of the above

questions.solution:
IgD and IgM occur on the surface of unstimulated B lymphocytes. It acts as a recognition receptor for antigen and causes specific stimulation of the B cell - either activation or cloning to produce antibodies or suppression.

IgA: (Option A ruled out)

  • Two types – IgA1 and IgA2
  • Major immunoglobulin in colostrum, saliva, and tears
  • Two Forms: Monomeric serum IgA and dimeric secretory IgA
  • Secretory IgA:
    • Two monomer units joined together at their carboxy terminals by a glycopeptide termed the J chain
    • Produced by plasma cells near mucosal or glandular epithelium
    • Secretory piece or secretory component in the IgA protects IgA from bacterial proteases, especially in areas with abundant bacterial flora (e.g., intestines)
    • Role in Local Immunity: Concentrated in secretions, it forms an "antibody paste" on mucosal surfaces to protect against respiratory and intestinal pathogens.
    • Resistance: Relatively resistant to digestive enzymes and reducing agents
    • Activates the alternative complement pathway

IgD: (Option B)

  • IgD and IgM occur on the surface of unstimulated B lymphocytes
  • Function:
    • Acts as recognition receptors for antigens
    • It causes specific stimulation of the B cell - either activation or cloning, to produce antibodies or suppression.

 

IgE: (Option C ruled out)

  • Heat-labile (sensitive to heat)
  • It has an affinity for the surface of tissue cells (particularly mast cells) of the same species (homocytotropism)
  • Mediates Prausnitz-Küstner Reaction
  • Distribution: Primarily found in extravascular spaces
  • Elevated Levels: In atopic conditions (type I allergies) like asthma, hay fever, eczema, and parasitic infections
  • Function: Protects against pathogens by triggering mast cell degranulation and releasing inflammatory mediators

 

Immunoglobulin Functions:

  • IgG: Protects body fluids
  • IgA: Protects body surfaces
  • IgM: Guards the bloodstream
  • IgE: Mediates allergic hypersensitivity
  • IgD: Present on the surface of B lymphocytes

questions.text: Which of the following is true about IgG, but not IgM?

choices.text: It requires a J chain for polymerisation.
It has a valency of 10.
It is the only antibody that can cross the placenta.
It is the first antibody produced by the fetus.

questions.solution:
IgG is the only maternal antibody transported across the placenta, providing passive immunity to newborns.

 

IgG

  • Four types – IgG1, IgG2, IgG3, and IgG4
  • It is the main serum immunoglobulin, constituting 80% of total serum antibodies
  • Distribution: Both intravascular and extravascular
  • Only maternal antibody transported across the placenta, providing passive immunity to newborns (Option C) mop
  • Function:
    • Binds to microorganisms, enhancing their phagocytosis
    • Participates in complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralisation of toxins/viruses
    • Part of chronic inflammation
  • Clinical Application: Used in isoimmunisation for Rh-negative mothers with anti-Rh(D) IgG during delivery.

 

IgM

  • It is a heavy molecule, hence called 'the millionaire molecule.’
  • Structure: Made of five four-peptide subunits; requires a J chain for polymerisation (Option A ruled out)
  • Valency: 10 (Option B ruled out)
  • Distribution: Primarily intravascular (80% of IgM)
  • Early Production: First antibody synthesized by the fetus, starting around 20 weeks of gestation (Option D ruled out)
  • Short-Lived: IgM antibodies degrade sooner than IgG
  • Immune Hemolysis: One IgM molecule can induce hemolysis, unlike IgG, which requires 1,000 molecules for similar effect
  • Opsonization Efficiency: 500-1,000 times more effective in opsonization than IgG

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the enzymatic digestion of immunoglobulins is incorrect?

choices.text: Papain digestion results in the formation of two Fab fragments and one Fc fragment.
Mercaptoethanol irreversibly cleaves disulfide bonds, separating heavy and light chains.
Pepsin digestion produces one F(ab')2 fragment and several smaller peptide fragments.
Pepsin digestion cleaves the Ig molecule above the disulfide bridge in the hinge region.

questions.solution:
Pepsin digestion actually cleaves below the disulfide bridge in the hinge region, leading to the formation of an F(ab')2 fragment and additional smaller fragments.

Enzymatic Digestion of Immunoglobulins

Papain Digestion

  • Mechanism:
    • Cleaves Ig above the disulfide bridge in the hinge region.
  • Results:
    • Generates three fragments: (Option A)
      • Two Fab Fragments:
        • Soluble fragments that bind to antigens (Ag).
      • One Fc Fragment:
        • Insoluble, crystallizes when cold.

 

Pepsin Digestion

  • Mechanism:
    • Cleaves the Ig molecule below the disulfide bridge in the hinge region.
  • Results:
    • Produces: (Option C)
      • One F(ab')2 Fragment:
        • Two Fab subunits are still bound together.
      • Many Smaller Fragments:
        • Additional peptide fragments result from further cleavage.

Mercaptoethanol (Option B)

  • Function:
    • Irreversibly cleaves disulfide bonds.
  • Outcome:
    • Separates all heavy chains and light chains of the immunoglobulin.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is preparing for a trip to Africa and South America. The healthcare provider informs him that he needs a yellow fever vaccine, which is important for preventing the disease. Which of the following statements about the yellow fever vaccine is incorrect?

choices.text: The vaccine is effective in providing long-lasting immunity
Immunity from the vaccine develops immediately after vaccination.
The vaccine contains a live attenuated virus
It is a form of artificially acquired active immunity.

questions.solution:
This statement is incorrect because immunity typically takes a few weeks to develop after vaccination.

Active immunity

  • The most common type of immunity developed in response to infection or vaccination.
  • Characteristics:
    1. Resistance developed as a result of antigenic stimulation.
    2. Used for prophylaxis to enhance body resistance.
  • Types:
    1. Natural Active Immunity
    2. Artificial Active Immunity

Naturally acquired active Immunity

  • Development:
    • Forms after exposure to antigens via natural processes (e.g., infection).
    • The body's immune system produces antibodies in response.
  • Duration:
    • It can be long-lasting (e.g., smallpox, measles, chickenpox, yellow fever).
    • May diminish over time (e.g., diphtheria, tetanus, influenza).
  • Premunition:
    • A special type of immunity observed in syphilis, is also called infection immunity.
    • Rapidly acquired, short-lived, and partially effective.
    • Immunity lasts only as long as the original infection is active.

Artificially acquired active immunity

  • Definition:
    • Induced by vaccination.
  • Process:
    • Carefully chosen antigens (e.g., vaccines, toxoids) are intentionally introduced.
    • The immune system synthesizes antibodies in response.
  • Immunity duration:
    • Typically provides long-term immunity.
  • Vaccines available:
    • Against diseases such as cholera, tuberculosis, plague, pneumonia, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, smallpox, polio, tetanus, influenza, measles, rabies, and yellow fever.
  • Toxoids:
    • Available for protection against diphtheria and tetanus, where major effects are due to toxins.

Options(A, C, and D) are accurate. The vaccine provides long-lasting immunity, contains a live attenuated virus, and represents a form of artificially acquired active immunity.

 

Learning Objective:

 

Category

Passive immunity

Source

Produced by the individual's own immune system.

Acquired from an external source

Mechanism

The immune system responds to the antigen by producing its own antibodies

Pre-formed antibodies are transferred into the individual.

Onset of Immunity

It takes time to develop

Immediate protection after administration.

Duration of Immunity

Long-lasting

Short term

Quality

Has high quality and is more effective

This is transient and less effective

Memory Formation

The immune system retains the memory of the pathogen.

No memory is formed; immunity is not long-term.

On subsequent dose

Shows booster effect

Is less effective

In Immunodeficient

It may be ineffective or insufficient in patients with severe immunodeficiencies

Critical for immunodeficient individuals

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with complaints of persistent fatigue, bone pain, and frequent infections. Laboratory tests reveal anemia, hypercalcemia, and elevated serum protein levels. A peripheral blood smear shows rouleaux formation. Which of the following statements regarding the types of antibodies produced is correct?

choices.text: The antibodies recognize different epitopes and show variability.
The antibody population includes both kappa and lambda light chains.
The antibodies are identical across batches and highly cross-reactive.
The antibodies are homogeneous from a single clone of B cells.

questions.solution:
• The clinical features of this patient suggest multiple myeloma, which is characterized by the production of monoclonal antibodies from a single clone of B cells.
  • This results in a homogeneous population of antibodies targeting a specific epitope.

 

Feature

Monoclonal Antibodies

Polyclonal Antibodies

Definition

Homogeneous population produced by a single clone of plasma B cells

The mixture of immunoglobulin molecules from multiple clones of plasma B cells

Antibody Population

Homogeneous

Heterogeneous

Epitope Interaction

Interact with a particular epitope on antigen

Recognize different epitopes on the same antigen (Option A)

Cross Reactivity

Low cross-reactivity

Increased likelihood for cross-reactivity with similar antigens (Option C)

Lot Variability

Identical lots

Lot-to-lot variability

Light Chains

Same type of light chain is produced (e.g., in multiple myeloma)

May have both Kappa (K) and Lambda (λ) light chains (e.g., in infections) (Option B)

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of fatigue, sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. On examination, he has significant posterior cervical lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. The physician suspects a viral infection and decides to perform a specific agglutination test. Which of the following statements regarding this test is correct?

choices.text: The test detects heterophile antibodies that agglutinate sheep red blood cells.
An agglutination titer of 50 or below is indicative of a positive result.
The test requires fresh serum samples without any prior heating.
Heterophile antibodies are produced only in response to one type of virus

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) The test detects heterophile antibodies that agglutinate sheep red blood cells.

  • This scenario is indicative of infectious mononucleosis (IM).
  • This statement accurately describes the principle behind the Paul-Bunnell test, which is used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).
  • The test identifies heterophile antibodies present in the patient's serum that can agglutinate sheep red blood cells, which is a characteristic immune response associated with this viral infection.

 

Heterophile Antigens

  • Definition:
    • A type of hetero-antigen present in different species that share epitopes.
  • Cross-Reactivity:
    • Antibodies produced against an antigen from one species can react with the heterophile antigen from another species and vice versa (Option D)
  • Diagnostic Applications:
    • Heterophile antigens are used in various serological tests to detect antibodies in patient serum.
    • Examples of Tests:
      • Weil-Felix Reaction: Used to diagnose certain infections, such as rickettsial infections.
      • Paul-Bunnell Test: Primarily used for diagnosing infectious mononucleosis.
      • Cold Agglutination Test: This test is used to detect specific antibodies that cause agglutination at low temperatures.
        • This test is primarily used to identify mycoplasma pneumonia.
      • Streptococcus MG Test: Used to detect antibodies associated with streptococcal infections.

Paul-Bunnell Test

  • Purpose:
    • Diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus.
  • Method:
    • Utilizes sheep red blood cells (RBCs) as antigens to detect heterophile antibodies in the patient’s serum.
  • Principle:
    • In infectious mononucleosis, heterophile antibodies agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.
    • These antibodies can also occur after serum injections and in some normal individuals.
  • Procedure:
    • The inactivated serum is prepared by heating at 56°C for 30 minutes (Option C)
    • The serum is mixed in doubling dilutions with an equal volume of a 1% sheep erythrocyte suspension.
    • Incubate at 37°C for 4 hours.
  • Interpretation:
    • Examine for agglutination.
    • An agglutination titer of 100 or above suggests infectious mononucleosis (Option B)

Note: The Paul-Bunnell test uses sheep erythrocytes; the Monospot test, horse red cells.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with high fever, hypotension, and a diffuse rash. He reports having eaten at a barbecue the previous day, where he consumed undercooked food. He is also experiencing confusion and severe muscle pain. Laboratory tests reveal elevated inflammatory markers. Which of the following statements regarding the mechanism of his condition is correct?

choices.text: The active proteins bind directly to the lateral aspect of the T cell receptor β chain.
The immune response involves specific antigen recognition by TCR α chains and MHC molecules.
The proteins involved are typically small peptides with a molecular weight under 10 kDa.
They induce massive release of cytokines, such as IL-2, leading to lymphocyte apoptosis.

questions.solution:
• This is a case of toxic shock syndrome (TSS), likely due to a superantigen produced by Staphylococcus aureus.
  • These active proteins bind directly to the lateral aspect of the T cell receptor (TCR) β chain, bypassing the need for specific binding to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules.
  • This mechanism allows superantigens to engage a large number of T cells regardless of their antigen specificity, leading to extensive T cell activation. As a result, there is a massive release of cytokines.

Superantigens:

  • Definition: Superantigens are protein molecules that activate large numbers of T cells regardless of their antigenic specificity.
  • Binding Mechanism:
    • Bind directly to the lateral aspect of the T cell receptor (TCR) β chain.
    • Unlike conventional antigens, which bind to the TCR α/β heterodimer via the MHC molecules (Option B)
  • Molecular Weight: Typically medium-sized proteins (22-29 kDa) (Option C)
  • Stability: Highly resistant to proteases and denaturation.
  • Target Cells: Primarily activate CD4+ T cells.
  • Cytokine Release: Induce massive release of cytokines, such as IL-2.
  • Effects on Lymphocytes: Lead to significant proliferation of lymphocytes (Option D)
  • Cytokine Cascade: Result in further release of various cytokines, profoundly affecting the immune system.

Food poisoning, Toxic shock syndrome, Multiple sclerosis

Group A streptococci

Shock, Rheumatic heart disease, Psoriasis

Not identified

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman visits the clinic for evaluation of her immune response following a recent vaccination. The physician discusses the differences between T cell-dependent and T cell-independent antigens. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: T cell-independent antigens can activate complement
T cell-dependent antigens result in a limited range of antibody isotypes.
T cell-independent antigens primarily lead to the production of IgM and IgG3.
T cell-dependent antigens generate immunologic memory.

questions.solution:
T cell-dependent antigens typically result in a full range of antibody isotypes, including IgM, IgG, IgA, and IgE, rather than a limited range.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is most likely to decrease the immunogenicity of a substance?

choices.text: Large molecular size of the antigen
Metabolic resistance to degradation by enzymes
Parenteral route of administration
Presence of adjuvants

questions.solution:
Immunogenicity requires antigens to be broken down by phagocytic cells. Substances resistant to enzymatic degradation, like polystyrene latex, cannot be processed effectively, reducing their immunogenicity.


 

Factors Affecting Immunogenicity:

 

Factor

Description

Details

Molecular Size

Larger molecules are more immunogenic.

(Option A ruled out)
  • High MW molecules (e.g., hemocyanins) are strongly antigenic.
  • Small molecules (<5000 MW) are weak or non-antigenic.

Chemical Nature

Composition affects immunogenicity.
  • Proteins and polysaccharides are highly antigenic.
  • Lipids and nucleic acids are weak antigens, but binding to proteins enhances their antigenicity.

Foreignness

Non-self substances are immunogenic.
  • "Self" substances are non-immunogenic.
  • The degree of foreignness matters; antigens from the same species are less immunogenic than those from other species.

Susceptibility to Enzymes

Immunogenic substances must be metabolically degradable.
  • Antigens require a breakdown by phagocytes for immune cell recognition.
  • Substances resistant to degradation (e.g., polystyrene latex) are non-antigenic.

Route of Administration

Route influences the immune response.
  • Parenteral administration (e.g., injection) elicits a stronger response than oral/nasal. (Option C ruled out)
  • Injection site matters (e.g., hepatitis B vaccine is more effective in the deltoid than the gluteal muscle).

Antigen Dose

Dose impacts immune response strength.
  • An optimal dose is required for a strong response.
  • High doses can cause immunological paralysis.
  • Repeated exposure enhances response.

Adjuvants

Enhance immunogenicity through various mechanisms. (Option D ruled out)
  • Depot adjuvants (e.g., aluminium hydroxide) increase antigen persistence.
  • Immunostimulatory adjuvants (e.g., Freund's complete) activate immune cells.

Genetic Factors

Genes influence immune response to specific antigens.

Immune response (Ir) genes control individual immune responses to particular antigens.

Age and Nutritional Status

Age and nutrition affect immune system maturity.
  • Immune development is gradual; infants and young children are less responsive.
  • Malnutrition suppresses immune responses.
